questions.questionText: A simple pendulum with length $!$l$!$ makes 75 complete oscillations over four minutes. Find the length, $!$l$!$, of the pendulum.

steps.stepText: First, let's find the time period of the pendulum. What formula can be used to find the time period?
steps.stepText2: Calculate the time period of the pendulum up to 1 decimal place (in $!$s$!$).

steps.stepText: Now, the time period is known to be $!$3.2 s$!$. Using this, how would you find the length, $!$l$!$, of the pendulum?
steps.stepText2: Calculate the length of the pendulum up to 1 decimal places (in $!$m$!$).

options.optionText: Use the formula $!$T = \frac{\text{time (in seconds)}}{\text{number of oscillations}}$!$

questions.questionText: A vertical, cylindrical buoy of mass $!$0.42 kg$!$ is floating in the ocean. At $!$t = 0$!$ ,the buoy is displaced vertically downwards by a distance of $!$28 cm$!$ and begins to oscillate with simple harmonic motion. When the buoy is $!$15 cm$!$ above the water surface, the restoring force that acts on the buoy is $!$1.7 N$!$. What is the maximum acceleration of the buoy?

steps.stepText: We know that the buoy is undergoing simple harmonic motion. Based on this information, which of the following is true?

options.optionText: The restoring force on the buoy is proportional to its displacement from the equilibrium position and acts in the opposite direction to the displacement
The net force on the buoy is zero
The two forces acting on the buoy - gravity and buoyancy - are equal and opposite

steps.stepText: Since the restoring force $!$F$!$ is proportional to the displacement $!$x$!$ and acts in the opposite direction to the displacement, it can be written as $!$F = -kx$!$ where $!$k$!$ is proportionality constant. Calculate the value of $!$k$!$ up to 3 decimal places (in $!$N/m$!$).
When will the buoy have maximum acceleration?

options.optionText: When the buoy is at its maximum displacement
When the buoy is at its equilibrium position

steps.stepText: Now that we have the value of $!$k$!$, you can use it to calculate the maximum force on the buoy. And then, calculate the maximum acceleration of the buoy up to 1 decimal place (in $!$m/s^2$!$).
